ai_page.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Ealing - Page
ai_page.body:
Apply for landlord’s consent for building works

If you are planning to carry out alterations or improvements to your council home, you may need to get written permission (landlord's consent) from Ealing Council before starting any work.

When do you need landlord’s consent?

  • For major alterations, such as removing walls, installing central heating, or fitting new windows.
  • For works that may affect the structure or safety of the building.
  • For changes to shared (communal) areas.

How to apply

  1. Read the guidance on what you need permission for and how to apply.
  2. Download and complete the landlord’s consent application form.
  3. Send the completed form and supporting documents to housingpermissions@ealing.gov.uk.

What happens next?

We will review your application and may arrange a visit to inspect your home. You may be refused permission if the work could damage the property or breach health and safety regulations.

If you do not get consent

Carrying out improvements without the council’s written permission may breach your tenancy agreement, and you could be asked to reinstate the property at your own expense or face legal action.

Further information

  • Read the improvements and alterations guidance.
  • Contact us at housingpermissions@ealing.gov.uk if you need advice.

ai_business_case.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Ealing - Business Case
ai_business_case.letter:
To the CEO,

After reviewing the recent user feedback and associated issues regarding our online guidance for flat improvement permissions, I recommend targeted improvements to enhance both user experience and operational efficiency.

Positive Feedback:
The assessment indicates that the provided information does answer the core query about applying for permission, which is a positive sign of clarity. Great work to the web team for creating content that is informative and helpful.

Areas for Improvement:
However, users like David, who represents a typical council tenant, express uncertainty about processing times, specific approval criteria, and the step-by-step application process. These ambiguities can lead to frustration, increased inquiries, and potential delays, all of which consume valuable council resources.

Specific Recommendations:
1. Incorporate Estimated Timelines:
   - Add an approximate processing time (e.g., "We aim to review applications within 4 to 6 weeks") at relevant points. 
   - Impact: Reduces user anxiety, minimizes follow-up inquiries, and streamlines case management.

2. Clarify Approval Criteria with Specific Examples:
   - Develop a detailed list of improvements requiring permission (e.g., installing kitchens, handrails, structural changes).
   - Impact: Users will better understand what is needed upfront, decreasing incorrect submissions and potential non-compliance issues.

3. Implement a Clear, Step-by-Step Checklist:
   - Create a concise, numbered process guide outlining each step—from reading the guidance to submitting the application.
   - Impact: Simplifies decision-making for users, reduces perceived complexity, and accelerates submission quality.

By focusing on these enhancements, we can significantly improve the user experience, increase first-time successful applications, and reduce administrative overhead. This approach aligns with our goal to deliver efficient, citizen-centered services while also achieving cost savings through reduced follow-up and correction processes.

I recommend prioritizing these updates on the application guidance page, employing user-friendly language and visual aids where possible. This strategic refinement will ensure tenants like David feel confident and well-informed, ultimately fostering trust and satisfaction with council services.

Respectfully,

[Your Name]
Web Usability & Service Improvement Lead
